text: morning everybody and welcome to the second annual AWS Summit in Chicago my
name is Matt Wood and I'm delighted to join you here for a keynote where we'll have some customer speakers telling you
about how they're using AWS and who knows uh some new news as well we have
over 7,000 people registered to attend this event uh we have over 8,000 joining us on the live stream as well watching
on aws.amazon.com and I'm delighted to be able to say that we have 54 deep
technical sessions across the AWS family today and we have over 70 different Expo
partners that are building out their business on AWS for you to go and interview and talk to at the Expo after
the keot so without further Ado we've got a lot to get through let's get started when I joined Amazon web
services in 2010 uh I was based over in Europe and you basically only had to say
the word cloud computing before I would jump on a flight and come and talk to you and this was one of the first clouds
that I would have probably showed you you can see our beautiful color scheme uh blue and yellow here and this outlines from 2010 the benefits of cloud
computing and these seem very familiar to us all now the benefits of moving from a capex to an Opex model the
ability to be able to pay as you go and only pay for what you use the ability to have elastic capacity and scale up when
you need it and back down when you no longer need it to be able to get a faster time to Market without worrying about the undifferentiated heavy lifting
associated with building out infrastructure and if you fast forward just 6 years it's pretty amazing at the
transformation that's taking place AWS in 2016 looks like a very different Beast uh we're growing at 70% year
on-year and today we have over a million active customers per month on the platform and we Define an active
customer by somebody that is external to amazon.com that's actually using the platform these aren't just accounts that
are see sitting there not being used these are customers that are really using the platform monthin month out
every year uh Gartner publishes a magic quadrant which shows how all the uh cloud computing infrastructure of the
service landscape is evolving and in the last coverage of the Gart magic quadrant
uh they reported that today AWS has 10 times the compute capacity in use of the
14 others in the magic quadrant combined so we're growing pretty quickly and we're now at a$1 billion run rate as a
business and we're actually the fastest technology company to reach reach that landmark in just a little under 10 years
so AWS today looks very different from AWS in 2010 when I joined and it has become the infrastructure technology
platform of choice for a large number of organizations when we started AWS we
assumed that the idea of a move to operational model and the elasticity of the cloud would be most relevant to
startups and for sure we have a large number of startups that have grown very successful on AWS today whether it's
Pinterest Airbnb stripe slack Domo Periscope and a number of others that
you've probably heard of on this slide but what we saw was it wasn't just the move from a capital to an operational
model that was beneficial startups Lov the ability to be able to move quickly and the agility that the cloud was
giving them it turns out that that's just as relevant to Enterprise customers and so today whether it's oil and gas
Health Care manufacturing Financial Services retail or media we have a large
number of Enterprise customers that are running material meaningful production workloads up in the
cloud to support those customers we also have a large number of Partners and we also have a large number of public
sector customers today our public sector business is pretty healthy uh we have 2,000 government agencies running on AWS
today we have over 5,000 academic institutions and 18,000 nonprofits up
and running on AWS and you may see your Alma mat on the slide behind me in addition to that we have thousands of
system integrators uh from the large global system integrators like it centure and Booze Allen cognizant all
the way through to the cloud native born in the cloud startups such as secondat and a large number of isvs building out
software on AWS all the way from Adobe Aqua atlassian Autodesk Splunk and info
and what we see across all of these different uses all of these millions of different customers running on the
platform every single month is we see Innovation across virtually every industry Unleashed as a result of using
AWS so whether it's Bristol Meers squib who are able to use AWS to drive a dramatic reduction in the time it took
to run their clinical trials and 98% reduction and that means that clinical trials move more efficiently and get
drugs to Market more quickly or whether it's in gaming with supercell where they were recently launched a new game Clash
Royale their most recent and successful launch to date it's a great game if you haven't played it you can download it
after the keynote and they're able to scale to millions of concurrent players right at launch or ml
who installed missile tracking technology in all of their uh Major League Baseball stadiums in order to be
able to track the ball and the players in real time generating and receiving petabytes of data every season and
analyzing that data to give real-time statistics on whether someone should have slid into first base or not or
whether it's finra who are able to replay billions of Trades instantly on AWS so across virtually every industry
we're seeing tremendous amounts of innovation so what I thought I'd do in the keynote this morning was just run
you through some patterns some trends that we're seeing for customers in how they're innovating and they kind of fall
into three kind of Mega Trends and we'll go on from there so the first mega Trend
and what is driving a huge amount of innovation across these different Industries is the ability to be able to
remove constraints information inside an organization is its lifeblood and be
able to move and use that information in a meaningful way drives the organization and the more easily and the more quickly
you can access and use that information the more quickly you can use it to make decisions and take feedback on those
decisions and feed that back into your process now technology has always held the promise of accelerating that process
of moving information and collaborating around information and getting more real value out of that information uh almost
from day one we even have a term for it Information Technology however over time in the old world where we building large
data centers and huge physical networks installing servers and procuring servers and configuring servers to te technology
which was designed to accelerate that work became a constraint in and of itself and so one of the trends that we
see with customers as they use AWS is they are starting to Unbound the creativity of their developers and their
teams through the use of technology technology is becoming the accelerant that it was promised to be instead of
the constraint that it had become in large physical infrastructure and at AWS we spent the
last 10 years building out a pretty robust deep broad platform of infrastructure technology Serv
at the base level we have our physical infrastructure this consists of 12 different geographic regions around the
world and we think of regions perhaps a little bit differently to the traditional model a region for us is a
collection of what we call availability zones and availability zones are one or more individual data centers which are
redundantly powered redundantly connected and a minimum distance apart so those availability zones are coupled
together to build highly available fault tolerance systems within a region we have 12 regions today and we have five
more coming online this year in Ohio Montreal UK India and ning in China we
also have 54 different pop networks on our Edge Network we have a large Global
Network which connects all these regions together for faster connectivity and we also have govcloud uh which allows you
to run itar compliant workloads on AWS and built on top of this are our
core infrastructure services that I'm sure many of you are familiar with the compute storage databases networking and
monitoring that make up the foundation of many applications running on AWS alongside that we spent time
building out and investing in a large number of platform Services based on analytics application and developer uh
acceleration mobile services devops and a new iot platform that we announced at
the end of last year we've also worked on a collection of Enterprise services to help
Enterprises migrate and adopt the cloud more easily so whether it's working with migration building out hybrid applications running
virtual desktops using Corporate email with workmail or collaboration with work dos Enterprises are using more and more
of these services to be able to move more quickly and of course the core of all of this this the the the central thing the
number one thing that we spend our time thinking about really relates to security and compliance so we spend a
lot of time thinking about identity and building out identity and access control services we to think a lot about key
management and how you can control your own Keys using the Key Management Service or using Hardware hsms we also
have configuration and compliance checks and we have built-in auditing so you can see who did what to when uh to which
resource on the AWS cloud and finally we have a very successful Marketplace which
is allows you to pull down products open source and third party from Sellers and we have over 200 million hours per month
of ec2 time being run on Marketplace products so addition to this very broad
set of services each one of these little boxes represents a deep set of functionality so for compute we don't
just have one or two instance types we have a broad selection of instance types for general purpose Computing high
performance Computing High memory Computing gpus IO High IO Computing even
dedicated instances for regulated workloads and we actually have twice as many as the nearest competitor for
compute instances the same is true for databases today we have six different database
engines available on the relational database service Aurora postgress MySQL
Maria DB and the traditional Oracle and SQL Server databases and these databases
aren't just running on RDS they also run in multi-az configurations so you can split your database for higher
availability if we take a look at identity and access control we have a very very deep and fine grain set of
identity and access controls which allow you to not just specify a high level role but get really fine grained and
granular on who can do what to which resource so you can say that a specific individual inside your organization
Steve can add a table to a specific RDS instance at a particular time only from
within uh the corporate Network you get very fine grain on how you control these
resources so I want to switch quickly back to Storage storage is an area which we uh which we launched uh with S3 10
years ago a large distributed highly available Object Store and we've added
to that over time to match as many workloads to the cloud as we can based on feedback from you our customers so
whether it's archival storage with glacia whether it's file systems with the elastic file system and The Block
store with the elastic Block store and inside that we have general purpose volumes for The Block store we have
provisioned iops and we have magnetic media and EBS the elastic Block store is
really one of the wonders of the world we spent a lot of time delivering on the Innovation on behalf of our customers to
provide latency sensitive transactional workloads a consistent High op High iops
environment to run so these are things like databases where they need latency sensitive transactional workloads
typically running on solid state so we made a lot of investments in solid state media running under the hood of the
elastic block service in addition to that we started to work with provisioned
iops and a burst model which is great for boot volumes and Devon test and low latency interactive applications which
allow you to reach a consistent Baseline of performance but then when you need additional burst you can just scale up
for a short period of time so we've done a lot of innovation under the hood to make this work with solid state drives
which are specifically good for these sort of Random Access transactional workloads and we asked a question not
too long ago uh can we innovate in the same way with Magnetic media now some of
you might think well what ises magnetic media have to offer ssds are where it's at but actually magnetic media and hard
drives have a couple of really nice characteristics if you're building out a large scale Cloud platform the first is
they're really really cheap uh so you can buy a lot of them uh the second is they have a particular characteristic
for sequential reads IE High throughput reads so we wanted to ask can we provide
a new service which would allow us to provide common sequential high
throughput performance using magnet magnetic media and so today we're announcing two new EBS volumes
specifically built for big data workloads and throughput the first is a throughput optimized HDD volume called
ST1 this provides up to 500 Meg per second at a remarkably low cost this is
a step level change for customers in the cost and performance of hard drives
which are still the optimal choice for Block storage for Big Data so up to 500
Meg per second at 42 cents per per gigabyte per month and for data which
you're accessing less frequently we have a cold HDD volume SC1 which provides 250
Meg per second at just 2 and a half cents per gigabyte per month that's cheaper than S3 so this is excellent for
big data workloads in fact this is the industry's best price performance for Block storage for these high throughput
workloads and commonly seen in log processing uh streaming data processing specifically Apache Kafka dat analytics
with map ruce and in fact map elastic map reduce will support these new block volumes straight out of the gate data
warehousing and less frequently accessed data that'll sit in colder volumes we've been very lucky to have some great
private beta participants of these new volumes uh local litics some of you may be familiar with are a life cycle
engagement platform for web and mobile applications they used in more than 37,000 apps and they're installed in 2
and a half billion devices using these new volumes localytics saved over 50% on
their monthly storage costs with reliable throughput or Confluence who SE saw the same 50% savings through
throughput without sacrificing performance partners are also getting in on the game with Partners like Splunk
who are now able to deliver robust infrastructure monitoring and operational intelligence using these volumes so these new volumes we're very
excited and they'll be available from Tomorrow the second Trend that we're
seeing is that more and more Enterprises are are able to move fast without sacrificing control in an Old World it
became common to think well I can either column a move fast or column B I can
stay secure and this is kind of a false Choice when you have the breadth of the infrastructure platform available to you
that we have on AWS today we provide the broadest set of accreditations and certifications whether it's PCI DSS
level three whether it's fisma Hipp uh uh workloads itar compliance that I talked about for and uh ret record
retention uh policies that you can apply to glacia with glacia volt loock in addition to this we have a
broad set of services to secure your applications running in the cloud whether you're using networking using
the virtual private cloud or the web application firewall which will keep the bad guys away from your web
app or identity with identity and access management where we have not just identity and access in the cloud but
also Federated identity with saml we have encryption services with the Key
Management Service which allows you to take your keys run them in a managed environment we have Cloud Hardware
security modules that give you even more control over access to the Keys and we have a new encryption SDK which allows
you to control the encryption of your data within your Java applications in addition to that we have a wide range of
compliance services so we have a service catalog which allows you to control who in your organization can access what
applications we have cloud trail which will give provide continuous auditing of all the API calls that come into your
AWS environment we have config and config rules which allows you to specify configuration of your environment and
then get notifications and take automated remediated action when a change happens to that uh to that
environment and we have a service called inspector which allows you to build best practices inside your continuous
delivery of your applications uh from a security perspective so we announced inspector in preview uh a reinvent our
developer conference in October last year and today we're making it generally available uh for all
customers so let's take a quick look at how to detect and remediate security issues with a Amazon inspector so first
of all inspector will sit next to next to your application and it will assess
the network the VMS the operating system and all the application configurations sitting alongside your application and
it will compare those against a built-in Content Library of common security standards and vulnerabilities
once you have that we'll run detailed reports and provide you a dashboard of how your application is performing
against these best practices and of course we'll audit the tests that were run and whether you are in or out of
compliance with full audit Trails inside cloud trail so that's available uh for all customers tomorrow and again we've
got a lot of customers and partners that are already integrating uh inspector
results into their applications for better visualization so in the old old world
where you had to choose between moving fast or staying secure today you can not only build application and environment
QA into your process you can build best practice and monitoring and evaluation
into your continuous delivery model what that means is you can now move fast and stay secure and so this is really
important to get the maximum value of your applications and the maximum value of AWS and to talk a little bit more
about that I'd now like to welcome to the stage Ben Wilson the CTO of G E oil and gas

train that helps to power things like data centers for AWS networks and probably the most important thing in in
my world is laptops for developers let see did to
go there we go um today we in in the oil and gas industry
you can imagine we're operating in an uncertain world uh in this uncertain World oil prices have plummeted gas

see people pulling back from the oil and gas industry at GE we're doubling down on the oil and gas industry the reason

make it more efficient and effective for our customers another example is uh LG
facilities where we transform natural gas into liquefied natural gas and we use technology for compression from our

Healthcare business so we actually have these things called pigs that go down a pipeline and do inspections for

pigs GE is turning into the first digital industrial uh organization in
the world we're putting sensors on all of our products we're pulling off terabytes and sometimes pedabytes worth
of data and in doing that we're using that to be able to make our products better and also more success and make
our customers more successful the real reason I'm here today is to talk about our Cloud

to dat and with those types of applications you know people often times look at the cloud and they say hey an
application has hundreds of thousands or millions of users that's not what we have we have applications that have tens
of users or maybe a hundred users and that's a very different profile with
that different profile we have to make sure we understand what's going on with every single one of them we have to tag
monitor measure and automate every one of them and start to create patterns that allow us to be make those reusable
without that we would never be successful a couple of examples of applications we have in the cloud uh sap
hybris which is our storefront on the web to be able to sell products to our customers
uh get paid which is a great application for us because we have a lot of invoices coming in and we create a single invoice
out of that really important the only gas industry when things aren't going so well WordPress we moved in so our 90% uh
cost reduction there but a really interesting one is called Epsilon has 750 terabytes worth of data that we have
to do analysis against and we've moved that to AWS too overall our our journey
is to get 500 apps into AWS and we believe that will provide us enough apps that will really make us successful in
the long run but one of the things that people want to talk about the most is what are the real benefits so you move
the apps so what happened what we've seen is a 52% total cost of ownership
reduction now a lot of people go oh that must be on storage or it must be on ec2 instances and although in some cases
that's that is true we were a highly virtualized environment already so we saw some benefit there but not so much
where we saw the greatest benefit is when we started using Tools in AWS that made a difference if you think about
things like Aurora as an example it's a metered database now so we tossed out
the uh databases we were using started using Aurora and you think back on that last slide about us tagging and
monitoring all those apps what we're able to do is leverage a whole bunch of data that comes out of trusted advisor
and cloudwatch that allows us to be able to know when our applications are being used by by users and not and you can
imagine 10 users 50 users 100 users odds are they're not using them at at night they're probably just using it for about
8 or 10 hours a day with that we're able to shut them down and then bring them back up when it's needed with things
like elastic beant stock driving down our costs and being able to make it a more resilient and durable application a
really important Point um the next thing I want to talk about is the AWS snowball it's a new
tool from AWS it's pretty nice tool we like it we're using it with our uh Epsilon project we're moving 750
terabytes and and we found this to be a good Tool uh we've moved our first 50 terabytes it took us roughly two weeks
we estimated it was going to take us 100 days or more to go do that and you can imagine we have another 700 terabytes or
14 uh snowballs that we still need to move we find it fast efficient and it works quite well at least for the
particular situation we're in the other thing people ask me about
quite often is what's next for us you've moved 350 apps you're seeing a total cost reduction of you know 50 2% what's
really next well we're moving all of our apps into the cloud right and for us inside AWS we're going to start moving
our engineering apps in the cloud because we want to provide a differentiated user experience for engineers so if you think about it our
Engineers are in Florence Italy in Aberdine Houston uh Singapore Shanghai
Perth they're all over the world they have 100 megabyte files that they're moving back and forth and with those
files it becomes very challenging to be able to make that work if we can put it all in AWS use a 10 gbit back plane to
be able to move the data and then use things like desktop as a service to be able to provide a differentiated user
experience it would be extremely helpful and it would really help us drive down costs and most importantly help to
eliminate data centers and that's a really important piece for us so that's my last slide thank you very much for
your attention have a great conference [Music]
great thank you Ben and I just love these large aggressive moves to the cloud it's great so another Mega Trend
that we see is the ability for organizations to be able to automate as much of their development and
infrastructure as possible with AWS everything is just an API call away
including a service which generates apis and if you're not familiar if you're new to aw us which we have some
new customers here today this is a very common continuous delivery model where you spin up your environment you QA that
environment using tools like config and inspector that we just talked about then you deploy your app inside that
environment and go ahead and build develop test and QA that app spinning this cycle this application disco life
cycle as quickly as you can and elastic beant stalk is a service that we have
which automates all of this for you uh whenever you need it all you need to do is simply upload your code and elastic
beant stalk sets up the environment qas the environment deploys the app and all you have to worry about is pushing new
versions of the app up into elastic beant stalk it's a great way to get up and running with AWS quickly and then
deliver at scale and elastic Bean stalk applications have a couple of different
components they have your app of course running in Java or net PHP node python
Ruby go whatever you like you can also deploy Docker containers and run multicontainer environments on elastic
beant stalk and these applications and containers are then delivered onto a platform and this is the army so the
base operating system of your platform and the app server the Tomcats the I the passengers the pumers the glass fishes
all sorts of animals uh that sit onside the platform and then over here on the right hand side we have all the AWS
infrastructure which elased Bean stalk is going to manage on your behalf the instances the autoscaling groups that
allow you to scale up and down and recover gracefully from failure low balancing to get the networking all
sorted across this distributed application and health checks to manage the health of your application and take
automated remediated action in the event of a problem now over here on the left hand
side that's typically the developer responsibility and over here on the right hand side that's kind of elastic
beant stalks bread and butter but over here in the Middle with the platform maintaining and operating and keeping
that platform up to date uh has become a kind of shared responsibility so when the Amazon Linux version increments it's
been the responsibility of our developers to go install that against their application and we want to make it as easy as possible for developers to
move quickly and stay secure and so we ask the question can we remove more of
the maintenance burden for web applications can we make it easier to manage the platform that your
application sit on top of in addition to the availability and the scale of your application the elastic bean stock is
known for And So today we're adding an update for elastic Bean stalk called platform updates which allow you to
safely and automatically keep your web application up to date and this will be available for all customers
tomorrow so managed updates for elastic Beanstalk allow you to keep your application platform up to date all the
operating system and the I servers and the web servers and the application containers all of that sits on the
platform and as soon as an update is detected uh we'll make sure that the application is deployed against the new
upto-date application without you having to worry about it you stay in control of platform updates so a little like bit
like you can do with RDS you can schedule maintenance Windows where this maintenance will take place and then
elastic bean store will safely perform the updates whilst maintaining availability of your application and the
way that does this is kind of cool elastic Bean will perform an automated blue green deployment so here we have a
very basic architecture of an elastic beanock application where we have requests coming into the low balancer
which then gets balanced across a number of nodes uh these instances are running on ec2 and if one fails then another one
Auto automatically gets replaced inside the group and you can add or remove capacity as your application needs to scale
automatically so when a new platform comes available uh elastic be St will spin up a blue green deployment it'll
keep the traffic pointed from the low balancer to the blue autoscaling group and it'll deploy the new version of the
platform and the application into the green autoscaling group and it'll run tests against that application to make
sure that everything is checked out before any traffic gets routed to it so after a single instance is spun up and
checks out it'll then populate the auto scaling group with the same number of instances as the previous Auto scaling
group and when all the tests there check out and only when the service is absolutely happy it'll swap the two over
it'll start to Route traffic into the green new version of the platform and the old version will disappear so this
is an immutable way of deploying and managing applications you can get rid of
the old version and instantiate a new version completely immutably so this is a new version new feature for elastic
beant stalk available tomorrow another Trend that we see is customers moving to simplify
relentlessly their development and their operations and S3 the simple storage
service was one of the first internet scale applications the internet scale building blocks which allowed developers
to focus more on their code and their application without having to worry about procuring a provisioning storage
and when we built S3 it had five very simple um seemingly um uh
characteristics it had to be extremely simple and easy to use it had to be scalable it had to be delivered at low
cost it had to be reliable and it had to be low latency and S3 became the first
internet scale component for applications which were growing quickly and these building blocks for
internet scale applications really took off and this is the foundation for uh a lot of the Innovation that we saw from
customers in the early days of AWS and right around the time when S3 was
really taking off with customers we asked a question can we apply the same approach can we take those same
characteristics of Simplicity and scale and low cost and apply them to other application components and this was the
origin of a functional Computing platform that we call AWS Lambda and AWS
Lambda has the exact same characteristics as S3 it's designed to deliver a serverless compute platform
which is simple and easy to use extremely scalable low cost reliable and low latency and the way that it works is
a little bit like S3 all you have to do is just deploy your code into Lambda
you'll get subsecond metering when those functions run and there are no servers at all to procure provision or manage we
allowed this two years ago and the adoption of Lambda has been remarkable we have a number of customers that are
running Lambda in production today across four kind of large buckets of usage which I'll we talk about a little
bit but uh ad roll is a really good example this is an ad retargeting platform which stores over 300 terabytes
of new compressed data in S3 every month and as new data gets added to S3 Lambda
functions respond automatically at whatever scale they need process that data so that their Downstream machine
learning teams can take advantage of it and combining both S3 and Lambda
together means that you can run entire web applications without having to worry about any servers and when it comes down
to it no server is easier to manage than no server at all so bule is a really good example of this bule started
experimenting with uh Lambda for real-time data processing using Kinesis
but they quickly found the benefits extended into running their core application themselves and they moved
into this common environment where you have the HTML of your application running in s in S3 you call uh API
Gateway which then calls Lambda on the back end to implement your application features as small microservices so
whether it's search or recommendations or common crud updates and then they talk typically to Dynamo DB on the back
end and the cost of running this is remarkably small and you can scale and
spend no time at all thinking about what happens when you need to scale to millions of different
users another really common usage is serverless data processing so I love
this example from firey firey is a intrusion detection system and sits on
top of Lambda and what they do is they have reimplemented map reduce
effectively inside Lambda so they have this cascading cause of Lambda functions calling Lambda functions working on data
in S3 which then Maps the data together reduces it back to get a result and they used to do this using elastic search
running on ec2 but they found the same exact performance if not better by moving to Lambda and they reduced the
cost by 80% by moving off elastic search running on ec2 so this is a really good use case for big data processing without
having to manage servers at all another common use case we see is in the Internet of Things uh some of you may
recognize this from our cousins over at Amazon retail this is Amazon Echo and Amazon Echo uh responds to your voice
you can say hey Alexa play music in addition to that Echo provides a development platform where you can
extend Alexa's skills using Lambda so all you have to do to add skills to
Alexa is to be able to write a single Lambda function plug it into Alexa and get it certified and then you can ask
Alexa anything that you want and because Lambda will scale and you don't have to worry about the servers under the hood
and you don't have to worry about the operations you can just write that single function in JavaScript or Java or
Python and it will respond from your Echo device so the platform that Alexa
provides with Alexa skills kit runs on top of Lambda it's very easy to use just from the website the fourth major area that
people are use customers are using Lambda for is to provide the connective tissue of their AWS environments so some
of you may be familiar with a new service which we launched a couple months ago called cloudwatch events this
gives you an event stream of everything that's taking place inside your AWS infrastructure and then allows you to
respond quickly and automatically using Lambda functions so Capital One are
using cloudwatch events and Lambda to build higher levels of compliance inside
their applications and if you want to know a little B more about that they're speaking in the protecting your data in AWS session this afternoon we also have
life cycle hooks for elastic low balancing so when something changes inside an autoscaling group you can get
a notification which Lambda will respond to config rules you can extend the rules inside the configuration monitoring
using Lambda and then remediate or notify if your application falls out of compliance and you can also run
scheduled jobs a lot like KRON using cloudwatch events and Lambda and a lot of customers in the ecosystem
specifically uh Splunk have really embraced Lambda to provide more functionality inside their
applications so those four areas have really driven uh Lambda to become the
connective tissue and become the default way of building serverless applications on
AWS the third major building block for internet scale applications is Amazon
Dynamo DB Dynamo DB is again one of the wonders of the world and it has the exact same characteristics you may be
seeing a pattern here of Simplicity scalability low cost reliability and low latency that S3 and Lambda were designed
with with in mind and we announced Dynamo DB and launched it about four years ago and the uptick and the success
of customers using it has been astonishing so here are just a few examples red finin with 5 billion items
we have Expedia that are running 200 million messages processed every single day mapbox that have over 200 million
users running on top of Dynamo DB and I'd like to introduce our next speaker
to talk a little bit about how they're using Dynamo DB please welcome Karen Sai from Duolingo
